The priests were responsible for pleasing the gods, an essential role that they fulfilled by making sacrifices and offering gifts. column3: Factories used various methods to use or cover up spoiled meat during the gilded age some of these methods include, "they would call upon their chemistry department, and preserve it with borax and color it with gelatin to make it brown. "All of their sausage came out of the same bowl, but when they came to wrap it they would stamp some of it 'special,' and for this they would charge two cents more a pound." This was not only disgusting, it was also dangerous as these chemicals could harm you and even cause death. "In the pickling of hams they had an ingenious apparatus, by which they saved time and increased the capacity of the plant—a machine consisting of a hollow needle attached to a pump; by plunging this needle into the meat and working with his foot, a man could fill a ham with pickle in a few seconds. And yet, in spite of this, there would be hams found spoiled, some of them with an odor so bad that a man could hardly bear to be in the room with them. To pump into these the packers had a second and much stronger pickle which destroyed the odor—a process known to the workers as 'giving them thirty per cent." "Also, after the hams had been smoked, there would be found some that had gone to the bad. Formerly these had been sold as 'Number Three Grade,' but later on some ingenious person had hit upon a new device, and now they would extract the bone, about which the bad part generally lay, and insert in the hole a white-hot iron. After this invention there was no longer Number One, Two, and Three Grade—there was only Number One Grade." This was disgusting as what should've been qualified as "Number Three Grade" which meant that the meat had gone bad was instead qualified as a "Number One Grade" even though the meat was bad and dangerous.
column4: Sure, here is the rewritten passage:  Factories employed various methods to conceal spoiled meat during the gilded age. Some employed chemistry to preserve it with borax and colored it with gelatin, making it brown. All sausage were made from the same bowl, but the wrapping process was marked by a small "special" stamp, costing two cents more per pound. Unsanitary conditions and the use of certain chemicals during the pickling process led to spoiled hams that went to the bad. A strong pickle was then used to eliminate the odor, while the smoked hams had a bone removed and replaced with a white-hot iron, resulting in "Number One Grade" status.

column4: Ancient Egypt's government was structured like the pyramids. It comprised multiple social classes, each with unique roles and responsibilities. The government was dominated by the gods and pharaohs, who held the highest positions. Below them were the nobles, priests, and viziers. In the middle were the scribes, who maintained the government records. At the bottom were the soldiers, who protected the people from the lower-ranked classes. The people who built the structures were the slaves, farmers, and peasant, forced to labor in exchange for food and shelter.

column3: To cover up spoiled meat the factory would use chemicals like borax to rid the meat of odor. They would also dye it brown so it was not noticeable to the public. Spoiled meat would be pickled or chopped into fine pieces and mixed into sausage. Upton Sinclair reveals that "Some of it they would make into "smoked" sausage – but as the smoking took time, and was therefore expensive, they would call upon their chemistry department, and preserve it with borax and color it with gelatin to make it brown. All of their sausage came out of the same bowl, but when they came to wrap it they would stamp some of it "special," and for this they would charge two cents more a pound." Even if the meat tasted different due to its rottenness they would cover that up by saying it was smoked and therefore should be worth more.
column4: "    The factory used chemicals to remove the odor from spoiled meat, dyeing it brown to conceal its appearance. They then mixed it into sausage and flavored it with preservatives to mask the rotten taste. Some of the sausage was smoked, but because of the time required for the process, they would add a special stamp to it, increasing the price by two cents per pound. This was done to compensate for the reduced profit of using preservatives. Even when the meat had an unpleasant smell, they would disguise it by claiming it was smoked and hence more valuable.

column3: At first, Jones starts off with a small class and emerges as the authoritarian figure in order to unite the class and make them all follow strict rules. This immediately resulted in increased efficiency, and people often follow the crowd even if bad things happen behind the scenes. Students from all over the school started joining the movement as they followed the crowd, and that's how it developed so quickly and effectively. The experiment was ended because of this, as it was growing so rapidly that Jones felt it would get out of control. So he ended the experiment to show the students how quickly an authoritarian figure can create a sense of superiority over others, and how quickly people follow the crowd regardless of what is happening.
column4: Sure, here is the rewritten passage in a similar number of words and writing ability level:  At first, Jones established a classroom setting where authority was exercised to unite the students and establish strict regulations. Consequently, people followed the crowd even when undesirable events transpired behind the scenes. Consequently, students from all corners of the school joined the movement, effectively spreading the message rapidly. However, the experiment was abruptly ended due to its rapid expansion, showcasing the potential for an authoritarian figure to create a perception of superiority over others and prompt immediate obedience to any guidance.

column3: The different classes are involvled with the government because like farmers grow crops and slaves do work and men and women do craftmenship to make tools, for the soilders to fight, like the author states "Social mobility was not impossible. column4: Here is the rewritten passage:  The government's involvement with the different classes highlights the intricate relationship between individuals and the state. Farmers cultivate crops and slaves engage in physical labor, highlighting the diverse roles that contribute to the nation's economic growth. Soldiers, like the author emphasizes, are drawn from diverse backgrounds and acquire skills through various means to contribute to the government. Social mobility was not merely restricted to a select few, as peasant and farmer communities demonstrated. Individuals, regardless of background, could access education, become scribes, and ascend to positions within the government, showcasing the interconnectedness of economic pursuits and the government's sphere of influence.

column4: "    The ancient Egyptian society was remarkably hierarchical. The divine occupied the apex of the pyramid; gods governed with absolute power. The elite included Pharaohs, who were extremely wealthy and relied heavily on advisors and scribes to ensure a steady supply of resources. The next group was the nobility and priesthood; priests played a crucial role in mediating between humans and the gods, while nobles were responsible for upholding social and political order through their government positions and wealth. The lower class was formed by the soliders, who maintained order by supervising the less affluent sections of society. The middle class consisted of skilled workers, artisans, and shopkeepers who were the backbone of the economy. The bottom rung of the social ladder was

column3: There are three elements of an ideal tragedy. First, the story should imitate pity and fear, however it shouldn't satisfy the reader in the moral sense. It should have a character that isn't perfectly good, but relatable and is undone by their own frailty or judgement. Second, the plot of a tragedy should be singular and the story shoud begin with the character in a good place and end with them in the bad. Thrid, the tragic story should have some sort of comedy, as the writer writes for the audience.
column4: A tragedy is a story that is both tragic and humorous, featuring a relatable and flawed character whose fate is ultimately destroyed through some error or flaw in judgment. The story should be unique and show the protagonist's journey from a good position to a poor one. Finally, a tragedy should include humor, as the author intends to draw attention to the situation and not satisfy the reader with a typical happy ending.

column3: All good tragedies have one huge distinctive similarity; the heartbreak it ensues. column4: Sure, here is the rewritten passage with a similar number of words and writing ability level:  The ancient Egyptian system of government had five main social classes. The pharaoh, the most important and powerful leader, held spiritual and political authority. Nobles followed the pharaoh and possessed important administrative roles. Priests were responsible for pleasing the gods through rituals and ceremonies. Craftsmen and women, in the middle class, produced and sold tools, utensils, and other objects for everyday use. Merchants and storekeepers played a crucial role in connecting with the public and facilitating trade and commerce.  The bottom class, including slaves and farmers, performed essential tasks that contributed to the survival of the society. Slavery was a harsh reality for many, as individuals were forcibly taken from their families and subjected to demanding labor and inhumane treatment.  The ancient Egyptian social structure demonstrates the importance of individual roles in a society, with each social class fulfilling vital roles that supported the smooth functioning of the state. The pyramid-like structure, with the pharaoh at the pinnacle, reflects the hierarchy and respect given to those who held high positions.

column3: As mentioned in the text, "Egyptian society was structured like a pyramid." The Pharaoh, who was worshipped as a  god,  was at the peak, with nobles and priests right below.  Below there were viziers, scribes and government officials. Next on the pyramid was soldiers and the middle class. The middle class was made of merchants and craftsmen. Soldiers worked for the government, and the middle class might not have always, joined the government, but at least they weren't at the very bottom. At the very bottom of the pyramid were farmers and slaves. As said by the text, "A small number of peasants and farmers moved up the social structure." this means that once you were in the lower class, it was almost impossible to climb out and become a part of the government. That is the location in the social structure that all people in Egypt were in, and how that affected their chances of being in the government.
column4: Ancient Egyptian society was hierarchical in structure. The pharaoh, worshipped as a god, occupied the highest position, followed by nobles and priests. Beneath them came lower-ranking officials, including viziers, scribes, government officials, soldiers, and the middle class. Soldiers worked for the government, while the middle class could hold various professions, although they typically didn't rise to government positions. At the bottom of the pyramid were farmers and slaves. It was challenging for individuals to advance in the social hierarchy, with most people remaining in their respective positions.

Moreover, paragraph 13 highlights the possibility for individuals born in humble backgrounds to rise to higher positions of power.

column3: At the top of the social pyramid are gods.  They had immense power, and could control their respective elements (Paragraph 1). Just below gods are pharaohs. Pharaohs were considered gods in human forms. They also had a load of power (Paragraph 1). Viziers were below pharoahs. The vizier insured taxes were collected. They also acted as a supervisor (Paragraph 4).  Scribes also worked with viziers. They were special, because they could read and write (Paragraph 5). Below all of these people were nobles and priests. Nobles were the only people allowed to hold government posts and profited from tributes paid to the pharoah (Paragraph 6). Priests were the religous leaders of Egypt. They kept the gods content so that they wouldn't bring misfortune to Egypt (Paragraph 6). Soldiers were below those two. They fought in wars and forcibly ended domestic uprisings. When it was peaceful, soldiers supervised peasents, farmers, and slaves who got involved in creating structures like pyramids and palaces (Paragraphs  8-10). Physicians and craftsmen/women were part of the middle class. They made jewelry, pottery, and papyrus products, tools, and all kinds of useful things (Paragraph 9). Of course, people had to buy good from these people. The people who bought these things were merchants and storepeople. These people sold these goods to the public (Paragraph 10). At the bottom of the barrel, we have slaves and farmers. Slavery was often the fate of prisoners of war. They wre forced to work on building projects, and toiled  at the discretion of the pharaoh or nobles (Paragraph 11)
column4: Sure, here is the reworded passage:  At the apex of the social pyramid stand gods, with immense power to shape the elements. Just below them are the pharaohs. They resembled gods in humanity, wielding great authority. Vizier, scribes, and nobles followed in that order. They served as either political figures or sought wealth from the pharaoh through tax collection and supervision. These individuals played diverse roles in maintaining order, constructing infrastructure, and managing the populace. Peasants, farmers, and slaves occupied the lower levels of society, serving the upper classes in tasks like building structures and managing domestic affairs.

column3:
The Third Wave developed over such a short period of time because the students were following the leader that they grew to trust and they followed each other in herd like behavior. Over that short period of time, Mr. Jones demonstrated how quickly and effectively he could get that group of students to obey and listen to him at all costs. The text states, "... they had been a part of an experiment to demonstrate how people willingly create a sense of superiority over others, and how this can lead people to justify doing horrible things in the name of the state’s honor." This example shows how the students felt that since they were apart of a group, they were above aanyone else who wasn't in the 
 specific group.
column4: The Third Wave emerged quickly because the students, trusting their leader, followed each other and obeyed his instructions promptly. Over time, this resulted in a sense of superiority among them. The text explains that the students participated in an experiment where they willingly created a sense of superiority over one another. This led them to justify doing horrific things in the name of the state's honor.

column3: An ideal tragedy should have its main character be someone who is highly renowned and prosperous, one who is not eminently good or bad, and they have an error in their ways or in their judgement that leads to their downfall. The change in the main character's fortune should also turn from good to bad.
column4: An ideal tragedy should center around a character who embodies duality, possessing both remarkable success and moral ambiguity. Their journey should witness a shift in fortune, with their initial good fortune transforming into a morally complex and dubious situation that drives their downfall.
